stem: A 22-year-old trauma client has been in a deep coma with fixed and dilated pupils for 48 hours following a severe traumatic brain injury (TBI). Based on the documentation in the provided tabs, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Initiating brain death determination protocol.
Background: 22-year-old male involved in a motor vehicle accident, resulting in severe diffuse axonal injury. Admitted 48 hours ago.
Assessment: At 07:00, the client's GCS is 3T, with no spontaneous respirations. Pupils are fixed and dilated bilaterally. Corneal and gag reflexes are absent. The client is ventilator-dependent and pressor-dependent to maintain a MAP >65 mmHg. Current vitals: BP 90/52, HR 68, Temp 95.2°F.
Recommendation: Continue brain death protocol per hospital policy. Neurology has ordered a formal apnea test. Notify the Organ Procurement Organization (OPO) per protocol if apnea test is positive.

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 90/52 (Pressor dependent), HR 68, RR 0 (Ventilator dependent), T 95.2°F (Poikilothermia).

actionOptions.text: Notify the local Organ Procurement Organization (OPO) as required by policy
Maintain hemodynamic stability (fluids/vasopressors) to preserve organ function
Inform the family that the ventilator is supporting the client's breathing

parameterOptions.text: Absence of brainstem reflexes and spontaneous respirations
Verification of a normothermic core temperature (> 36°C) for valid testing

rationale.correct: The client meets the clinical criteria for brain death (c2). Brain death is characterized by irreversible cessation of all functions of the entire brain, including the brainstem. Key findings include the absence of brainstem reflexes such as pupillary response, corneal reflex, and gag reflex, as well as the absence of spontaneous respirations (p1), confirmed by a formal apnea test. A critical prerequisite for accurate brain death determination is ensuring the client is normothermic (p2), as hypothermia can confound the assessment. Once brain death is confirmed, the nurse is responsible for notifying the OPO (a1) per hospital policy and maintaining hemodynamic stability (a2) to preserve organ viability if organ donation is being considered.
clinicalPearls: Poikilothermia, the inability to regulate body temperature, is a common finding in brain death due to hypothalamic dysfunction.
While the nurse plays a crucial role in the brain death determination process, the actual request for organ donation is the responsibility of the OPO representative.
Fixed and dilated pupils in brain death are typically mid-position (4-6mm).

questionTrap.trap: Assuming that initiating passive range-of-motion exercises is appropriate at this time.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: While range-of-motion exercises are important for immobile clients, the priority in brain death is to maintain hemodynamic stability for potential organ donation.

mnemonic.title: BRAIN DEATH
mnemonic.expansion: Brainstem Reflexes Absent, Respirations Absent (Apnea Test), Absent motor response, Irreversible, No recovery.
